FacilityName: A. Duda & Sons, Inc. - Belle Glade

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Please find attached Executive Summary for this RMP submission.
Executive Summary (Sec. 68.155)

(a)	The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source;

A. Duda & Sons, Inc. has a Hazard Communications Program in place implemented through the Duda Safety Department.  This program covers:  material inventory, material safety data sheets (MSDS), training, labels and warnings, responsibilities, recordkeeping, proper and safe handling procedures, personal protective equipment, emergency equipment, first aid procedures, emergency response procedures, along with employee responsibilities.

(b)	The stationary source and regulated substances handled;

In an effort to comply with Sec. 68.165 Offsite Consequence Analysis, a Hazard Assessment of the regulated toxic substance(s) on site at the Duda - Belle Glade facility was conducted.  The only regulated toxic substance on site is AMMONIA (anhydrous).  

(c)	The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario;

Results of the Consequence Analysis performed RMP*Comp Ver. 1.07 (EPA website): 

RMP*Comp Ver. 1.07
Results of Consequence Analysis

Chemical: Ammonia (anhydrous)
CAS #: 7664-41-7
Category: Toxic Gas
Scenario: Worst-case
Quantity Released: 8925 pounds
Release Duration: 10 min
Release Rate: 491 pounds per min
Mitigation Measures: Release in enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air

Topography: Rural surroundings (terrain generally flat and unobstructed)
Toxic Endpoint: 0.14 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2
Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint: 1.2 miles (1.9 kilometers)

--------Assumptions About This Scenario---------
Wind Speed: 1.5 meters/second (3.4 miles/hour)
Stability Class: F
Air Temperature: 77 degrees F (25 degrees C)
------------------------------------------------

No alternative release scenario(s) were n

ecessary, because facility is on the Program 1 Level.  Administrative/Mitigation measures are in place as there are no public and/or environmental receptors within the estimated distance to toxic endpoint of 1.2 miles (1.9 kilometers).  Location of substance is approximately 5 miles from public road access.   The regulated substance is located within the confines of the packinghouse (some areas are open-walled).  The release would occur in an enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air.

(d)	The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps;

Employees are trained through the Hazard Communications Program, Emergency Response Plans, and Hazwopper Training.

(e)	The five-year accident history;

Refer to Sec. 68.168 Five-Year Accident History.  Within the past five years, the process has had no accidental release that caused offsite impacts provided in the risk management program rule [40 CFR 68.10(b)(1)].

(f)	The emergency response program; and

	A copy of the Emergency Response Management Team is available at the location;

	The following excerpt is from the Hazard Communications Program for employees:

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURE
FOR A RELEASE OF A HAZARDOUS MATERIAL

1.	Evacuate all persons from the spill or release areas.
2.	Contact the Emergency Response Person at your location immediately.  It is the responsibility of the Emergency Response Person to notify the Corporate Offices within five (5) minutes in order for Corporate to notify the appropriate agencies within fifteen (15) minutes.
3.	Secure the spill and affected areas from accidental entry and disconnect ignition sources at the main panel.
4.	Begin first aid treatment to exposed personnel (only if you are properly trained in first aid).  Refer to labels and Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) for first aid procedures.
5.	Assist your supervisor and the authorities if your help is summoned.
